CancelPipelineReprocessing.name: CancelPipelineReprocessing
CancelPipelineReprocessing.documentation: Cancels the reprocessing of data through the pipeline.

CreateChannel.name: CreateChannel
CreateChannel.documentation: Creates a channel. A channel collects data from an MQTT topic and archives the raw, unprocessed messages before publishing the data to a pipeline.

CreateDataset.name: CreateDataset
CreateDataset.documentation:
Creates a data set. A data set stores data retrieved from a data store by applying an SQL action.

This operation creates the skeleton of a data set. To populate the data set, call "CreateDatasetContent".

CreateDatasetContent.name: CreateDatasetContent
CreateDatasetContent.documentation: Creates the content of a data set by applying an SQL action.

CreateDatastore.name: CreateDatastore
CreateDatastore.documentation: Creates a data store, which is a repository for messages.

CreatePipeline.name: CreatePipeline
CreatePipeline.documentation: Creates a pipeline. A pipeline consumes messages from one or more channels and allows you to process the messages before storing them in a data store.

DeleteDataset.name: DeleteDataset
DeleteDataset.documentation:
Deletes the specified data set.

You do not have to delete the content of the data set before you perform this operation.

DeleteDatasetContent.name: DeleteDatasetContent
DeleteDatasetContent.documentation: Deletes the content of the specified data set.

DescribeLoggingOptions.name: DescribeLoggingOptions
DescribeLoggingOptions.documentation: Retrieves the current settings of the AWS IoT Analytics logging options.

GetDatasetContent.name: GetDatasetContent
GetDatasetContent.documentation: Retrieves the contents of a data set as pre-signed URIs.

ListTagsForResource.name: ListTagsForResource
ListTagsForResource.documentation: Lists the tags (metadata) which you have assigned to the resource.

PutLoggingOptions.name: PutLoggingOptions
PutLoggingOptions.documentation:
Sets or updates the AWS IoT Analytics logging options.

Note that if you update the value of any loggingOptions field, it takes up to one minute for the change to take effect. Also, if you change the policy attached to the role you specified in the roleArn field (for example, to correct an invalid policy) it takes up to 5 minutes for that change to take effect.

RunPipelineActivity.name: RunPipelineActivity
RunPipelineActivity.documentation: Simulates the results of running a pipeline activity on a message payload.

SampleChannelData.name: SampleChannelData
SampleChannelData.documentation: Retrieves a sample of messages from the specified channel ingested during the specified timeframe. Up to 10 messages can be retrieved.

StartPipelineReprocessing.name: StartPipelineReprocessing
StartPipelineReprocessing.documentation: Starts the reprocessing of raw message data through the pipeline.

TagResource.name: TagResource
TagResource.documentation: Adds to or modifies the tags of the given resource. Tags are metadata which can be used to manage a resource.

UntagResource.name: UntagResource
UntagResource.documentation: Removes the given tags (metadata) from the resource.

UpdateDataset.name: UpdateDataset
UpdateDataset.documentation: Updates the settings of a data set.

UpdateDatastore.name: UpdateDatastore
UpdateDatastore.documentation: Updates the settings of a data store.

attributes.documentation:
A list of 1-50 "AttributeNameMapping" objects that map an existing attribute to a new attribute.

The existing attributes remain in the message, so if you want to remove the originals, use "RemoveAttributeActivity".

AddAttributesActivity.documentation: An activity that adds other attributes based on existing attributes in the message.

messageId.documentation: The ID of the message that caused the error. (See the value corresponding to the "messageId" key in the message object.)

channelName.documentation: The name of the channel where the messages are sent.

messages.documentation: The list of messages to be sent. Each message has format: '{ "messageId": "string", "payload": "string"}'.

batchPutMessageErrorEntries.documentation: A list of any errors encountered when sending the messages to the channel.

pipelineName.documentation: The name of pipeline for which data reprocessing is canceled.

reprocessingId.documentation: The ID of the reprocessing task (returned by "StartPipelineReprocessing").

retentionPeriod.documentation: How long, in days, message data is kept for the channel.

Channel.documentation: A collection of data from an MQTT topic. Channels archive the raw, unprocessed messages before publishing the data to a pipeline.

channelName.documentation: The name of the channel from which the messages are processed.

ChannelActivity.documentation: The activity that determines the source of the messages to be processed.

lastUpdateTime.documentation: The last time the channel was updated.

ChannelSummary.documentation: A summary of information about a channel.

retentionPeriod.documentation: How long, in days, message data is kept for the channel.

tags.documentation: Metadata which can be used to manage the channel.

retentionPeriod.documentation: How long, in days, message data is kept for the channel.

actions.documentation: A list of actions that create the data set. Only one action is supported at this time.

triggers.documentation: A list of triggers. A trigger causes data set content to be populated at a specified time or time interval. The list of triggers can be empty or contain up to five DataSetTrigger objects.

tags.documentation: Metadata which can be used to manage the data set.

retentionPeriod.documentation: How long, in days, message data is kept for the data store.

tags.documentation: Metadata which can be used to manage the data store.

retentionPeriod.documentation: How long, in days, message data is kept for the data store.

pipelineActivities.documentation:
A list of pipeline activities.

The list can be 1-25 PipelineActivity objects. Activities perform transformations on your messages, such as removing, renaming, or adding message attributes; filtering messages based on attribute values; invoking your Lambda functions on messages for advanced processing; or performing mathematical transformations to normalize device data.

tags.documentation: Metadata which can be used to manage the pipeline.

actions.documentation: The "DatasetAction" objects that create the data set.

triggers.documentation: The "DatasetTrigger" objects that specify when the data set is automatically updated.

lastUpdateTime.documentation: The last time the data set was updated.

actionName.documentation: The name of the data set action.

queryAction.documentation: An "SqlQueryDatasetAction" object that contains the SQL query to modify the message.

DatasetAction.documentation: A "DatasetAction" object specifying the query that creates the data set content.

state.documentation: The state of the data set. Can be one of "CREATING", "SUCCEEDED" or "FAILED".

reason.documentation: The reason the data set is in this state.

DatasetContentStatus.documentation: The state of the data set and the reason it is in this state.

entryName.documentation: The name of the data set item.

dataURI.documentation: The pre-signed URI of the data set item.

DatasetEntry.documentation: The reference to a data set entry.

creationTime.documentation: The time the data set was created.

lastUpdateTime.documentation: The last time the data set was updated.

DatasetSummary.documentation: A summary of information about a data set.

DatasetTrigger.documentation: The "DatasetTrigger" that specifies when the data set is automatically updated.

status.documentation:
The status of a data store:

CREATING

The data store is being created.

ACTIVE

The data store has been created and can be used.

DELETING

The data store is being deleted.

retentionPeriod.documentation: How long, in days, message data is kept for the data store.

lastUpdateTime.documentation: The last time the data store was updated.

datastoreName.documentation: The name of the data store where processed messages are stored.

DatastoreActivity.documentation: The 'datastore' activity that specifies where to store the processed data.

lastUpdateTime.documentation: The last time the data store was updated.

DatastoreSummary.documentation: A summary of information about a data store.

channelName.documentation: The name of the channel to delete.

datasetName.documentation: The name of the data set whose content is deleted.

versionId.documentation: The version of the data set whose content is deleted. You can also use the strings "$LATEST" or "$LATEST_SUCCEEDED" to delete the latest or latest successfully completed data set. If not specified, "$LATEST_SUCCEEDED" is the default.

datasetName.documentation: The name of the data set to delete.

datastoreName.documentation: The name of the data store to delete.

pipelineName.documentation: The name of the pipeline to delete.

channelName.documentation: The name of the channel whose information is retrieved.

channel.documentation: An object that contains information about the channel.

datasetName.documentation: The name of the data set whose information is retrieved.

dataset.documentation: An object that contains information about the data set.

loggingOptions.documentation: The current settings of the AWS IoT Analytics logging options.

pipelineName.documentation: The name of the pipeline whose information is retrieved.

pipeline.documentation: A "Pipeline" object that contains information about the pipeline.

attribute.documentation: The name of the attribute that is added to the message.

thingName.documentation: The name of the IoT device whose registry information is added to the message.

roleArn.documentation: The ARN of the role that allows access to the device's registry information.

DeviceRegistryEnrichActivity.documentation: An activity that adds data from the AWS IoT device registry to your message.

attribute.documentation: The name of the attribute that is added to the message.

thingName.documentation: The name of the IoT device whose shadow information is added to the message.

roleArn.documentation: The ARN of the role that allows access to the device's shadow.

DeviceShadowEnrichActivity.documentation: An activity that adds information from the AWS IoT Device Shadows service to a message.

filter.documentation: An expression that looks like an SQL WHERE clause that must return a Boolean value.

FilterActivity.documentation: An activity that filters a message based on its attributes.

datasetName.documentation: The name of the data set whose contents are retrieved.

versionId.documentation: The version of the data set whose contents are retrieved. You can also use the strings "$LATEST" or "$LATEST_SUCCEEDED" to retrieve the contents of the latest or latest successfully completed data set. If not specified, "$LATEST_SUCCEEDED" is the default.

timestamp.documentation: The time when the request was made.

status.documentation: The status of the data set content.

lambdaName.documentation: The name of the Lambda function that is run on the message.

batchSize.documentation:
The number of messages passed to the Lambda function for processing.

The AWS Lambda function must be able to process all of these messages within five minutes, which is the maximum timeout duration for Lambda functions.

LambdaActivity.documentation: An activity that runs a Lambda function to modify the message.

LimitExceededException.documentation: The command caused an internal limit to be exceeded.

nextToken.documentation: The token for the next set of results.

maxResults.documentation:
The maximum number of results to return in this request.

The default value is 100.

nextToken.documentation: The token to retrieve the next set of results, or null if there are no more results.
The token for the next set of results.

maxResults.documentation:
The maximum number of results to return in this request.

The default value is 100.

nextToken.documentation: The token to retrieve the next set of results, or null if there are no more results.
The token for the next set of results.

maxResults.documentation:
The maximum number of results to return in this request.

The default value is 100.

nextToken.documentation: The token to retrieve the next set of results, or null if there are no more results.
The token for the next set of results.

maxResults.documentation:
The maximum number of results to return in this request.

The default value is 100.

nextToken.documentation: The token to retrieve the next set of results, or null if there are no more results.

resourceArn.documentation: The ARN of the resource whose tags you want to list.

tags.documentation: The tags (metadata) which you have assigned to the resource.

roleArn.documentation: The ARN of the role that grants permission to AWS IoT Analytics to perform logging.

level.documentation: The logging level. Currently, only "ERROR" is supported.

enabled.documentation: If true, logging is enabled for AWS IoT Analytics.

attribute.documentation: The name of the attribute that will contain the result of the math operation.

math.documentation: An expression that uses one or more existing attributes and must return an integer value.

MathActivity.documentation: An activity that computes an arithmetic expression using the message's attributes.

messageId.documentation: The ID you wish to assign to the message. Each "messageId" must be unique within each batch sent.

activities.documentation: The activities that perform transformations on the messages.

reprocessingSummaries.documentation: A summary of information about the pipeline reprocessing.

lastUpdateTime.documentation: The last time the pipeline was updated.

channel.documentation: Determines the source of the messages to be processed.

lambda.documentation: Runs a Lambda function to modify the message.

datastore.documentation: Specifies where to store the processed message data.

addAttributes.documentation: Adds other attributes based on existing attributes in the message.

selectAttributes.documentation: Creates a new message using only the specified attributes from the original message.

filter.documentation: Filters a message based on its attributes.

math.documentation: Computes an arithmetic expression using the message's attributes and adds it to the message.

deviceRegistryEnrich.documentation: Adds data from the AWS IoT device registry to your message.

deviceShadowEnrich.documentation: Adds information from the AWS IoT Device Shadows service to a message.

PipelineActivity.documentation: An activity that performs a transformation on a message.

reprocessingSummaries.documentation: A summary of information about the pipeline reprocessing.

PipelineSummary.documentation: A summary of information about a pipeline.

loggingOptions.documentation: The new values of the AWS IoT Analytics logging options.

attributes.documentation: A list of 1-50 attributes to remove from the message.

RemoveAttributesActivity.documentation: An activity that removes attributes from a message.

creationTime.documentation: The time the pipeline reprocessing was created.

ResourceAlreadyExistsException.documentation: A resource with the same name already exists.

ResourceNotFoundException.documentation: A resource with the specified name could not be found.

unlimited.documentation: If true, message data is kept indefinitely.

numberOfDays.documentation: The number of days that message data is kept. The "unlimited" parameter must be false.

RetentionPeriod.documentation: How long, in days, message data is kept.

pipelineActivity.documentation: The pipeline activity that is run. This must not be a 'channel' activity or a 'datastore' activity because these activities are used in a pipeline only to load the original message and to store the (possibly) transformed message. If a 'lambda' activity is specified, only short-running Lambda functions (those with a timeout of less than 30 seconds or less) can be used.

payloads.documentation: The sample message payloads on which the pipeline activity is run.
The enriched or transformed sample message payloads as base64-encoded strings. (The results of running the pipeline activity on each input sample message payload, encoded in base64.)

logResult.documentation: In case the pipeline activity fails, the log message that is generated.

channelName.documentation: The name of the channel whose message samples are retrieved.

maxMessages.documentation: The number of sample messages to be retrieved. The limit is 10, the default is also 10.

startTime.documentation: The start of the time window from which sample messages are retrieved.

endTime.documentation: The end of the time window from which sample messages are retrieved.

payloads.documentation: The list of message samples. Each sample message is returned as a base64-encoded string.

expression.documentation: The expression that defines when to trigger an update. For more information, see Schedule Expressions for Rules in the Amazon CloudWatch documentation.

Schedule.documentation: The schedule for when to trigger an update.

attributes.documentation: A list of the attributes to select from the message.

SelectAttributesActivity.documentation: Creates a new message using only the specified attributes from the original message.

SqlQueryDatasetAction.documentation: The SQL query to modify the message.

pipelineName.documentation: The name of the pipeline on which to start reprocessing.

startTime.documentation: The start time (inclusive) of raw message data that is reprocessed.

endTime.documentation: The end time (exclusive) of raw message data that is reprocessed.

reprocessingId.documentation: The ID of the pipeline reprocessing activity that was started.

Tag.documentation: A set of key/value pairs which are used to manage the resource.

resourceArn.documentation: The ARN of the resource whose tags will be modified.

tags.documentation: The new or modified tags for the resource.

ThrottlingException.documentation: The request was denied due to request throttling.

resourceArn.documentation: The ARN of the resource whose tags will be removed.

tagKeys.documentation: The keys of those tags which will be removed.

channelName.documentation: The name of the channel to be updated.

retentionPeriod.documentation: How long, in days, message data is kept for the channel.

datasetName.documentation: The name of the data set to update.

actions.documentation: A list of "DatasetAction" objects. Only one action is supported at this time.

triggers.documentation: A list of "DatasetTrigger" objects. The list can be empty or can contain up to five DataSetTrigger objects.

datastoreName.documentation: The name of the data store to be updated.

retentionPeriod.documentation: How long, in days, message data is kept for the data store.

pipelineName.documentation: The name of the pipeline to update.

pipelineActivities.documentation:
A list of "PipelineActivity" objects.

The list can be 1-25 PipelineActivity objects. Activities perform transformations on your messages, such as removing, renaming or adding message attributes; filtering messages based on attribute values; invoking your Lambda functions on messages for advanced processing; or performing mathematical transformations to normalize device data.

documentation:
AWS IoT Analytics allows you to collect large amounts of device data, process messages, and store them. You can then query the data and run sophisticated analytics on it. AWS IoT Analytics enables advanced data exploration through integration with Jupyter Notebooks and data visualization through integration with Amazon QuickSight.

Traditional analytics and business intelligence tools are designed to process structured data. IoT data often comes from devices that record noisy processes (such as temperature, motion, or sound). As a result the data from these devices can have significant gaps, corrupted messages, and false readings that must be cleaned up before analysis can occur. Also, IoT data is often only meaningful in the context of other data from external sources.

AWS IoT Analytics automates the steps required to analyze data from IoT devices. AWS IoT Analytics filters, transforms, and enriches IoT data before storing it in a time-series data store for analysis. You can set up the service to collect only the data you need from your devices, apply mathematical transforms to process the data, and enrich the data with device-specific metadata such as device type and location before storing it. Then, you can analyze your data by running queries using the built-in SQL query engine, or perform more complex analytics and machine learning inference. AWS IoT Analytics includes pre-built models for common IoT use cases so you can answer questions like which devices are about to fail or which customers are at risk of abandoning their wearable devices.
